snippet: Cyrus Vance Jr. said that once New York State is completely current, he will pay to help other cities reduce their large backlogs of untested rape kits.
abstract: Editorial welcomes commitment from Manhattan District Atty Cyrus Vance Jr to use $35 million in civil forfeiture assets to help other jurisdictions reduce their backlogs of untested rape kits; contends Vance's decision admirably highlights dithering by cities, states and federal government on issue, but raises question of whether it is appropriate to use New York City assets to help meet out-of-state law enforcement needs.
lead_paragraph: Cyrus Vance Jr. said that once New York State is completely current, he will pay to help other cities reduce their large backlogs of untested rape kits.

headline.main: Manhattan’s D.A. Addresses a National Problem
headline.print_headline: Manhattan’s D.A. Addresses a National Problem
